descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Chris Webber scored 26 points to lead six players in double figures as the Kings extended their season-high winning streak to 11 games with their seventh straight victory over the Warriors, 121-97.
article.headline: Kings pull away for 11th straight victory

images.name: Webber, Chris 020118 inline
images.caption: Chris Webber had 26 points, eight rebounds and six assists for the Kings.

article.linkText: Kings keep focused vs. Warriors, win 11th straight
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- The Sacramento Kings are heeding coach Rick Adelman's warning about not getting too complacent. Chris Webber had 26 points, eight rebounds and six assists before fouling out Friday night as the Kings became the first team to win 11 straight games this season, defeating the Golden State Warriors 121-97. The Kings have won 15 consecutive games at Arco Arena, where they are an NBA-best 22-1. It was Sacramento's seventh straight win over the Warriors, who have lost eight of nine games. "I keep telling them when you get it going, you have to keep it going," Adelman said. "You can't go out and beat yourself." It was not the Kings best effort of the year, but it didn't have to be. The last-place Warriors, who were outscored 28-15 in the fourth quarter, have lost seven of eight games and have not won at Arco Arena since 1999. That streak was never seriously threatened as the Kings led by double figures throughout much of the game in improving to an NBA-best 30-9 overall. In a game where defense was mostly nonexistent, Sacramento broke the game open for good with a 9-0 run early in the fourth quarter. Bobby Jackson made a 3-pointer and Webber closed the run with a baseline drive, putting the Kings up 102-87 with 7:54 remaining. "It seems like our trademark, we get down, then we decide to play," Warriors forward Antawn Jamison said. "It was good to be close, but they have too many guns." Peja Stojakovic had 20 points for the Kings, who had all five starters and two reserves in double figures. Doug Christie had 16 points and six assists. Jackson had 13 points, both Hedo Turkoglu and Mike Bibby scored 12 points and Vlade Divac added 11 points, seven rebounds and eight assists. "The scary part is when you're playing this well, you can start taking shortcuts," said Webber, who fouled out with 6:42 remaining. "The better we're playing the more I want us to stick to the basics." Jamison scored 24 points for the Warriors and rookie Jason Richardson had 19. Danny Fortson contributed 15 points and 12 rebounds, while Larry Hughes had 11 points and nine assists. "Certainly the Kings are one of the best teams in the NBA," Richardson said. "I think we came in and played them hard the first three quarters. I think we gave a little bit in the fourth quarter, but that's what good teams like them do." Trailing by 14 points at the half, the Warriors opened the third quarter with a 13-4 run, cutting the lead to five points. Despite Jamison's 12 points in the third, the Kings still led 93-82 heading into the fourth period. "In the second half we had a false sense of security, we didn't defend and we turned the ball over and they were able to make it a close game," Adelman said. Showing their versatility on offense, the Kings raced to a 67-53 halftime lead. Webber led four players in double figures with 15 points for Sacramento, which shot 60 percent.

Game notes
Webber had 13 points and five first-quarter rebounds, helping the Kings to a 32-26 lead. ... Hughes missed his first eight shots before converting on a fastbreak layup midway through the second quarter. ... The Warriors made 13 of 22 shots in the third period.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
